questions.question_text: You have a member of your SECOPS team that is building custom scripts for your environment and they cannot save or share them in Falcon. What additional role do they need to be able accomplish this?

choices.B: All Real Time Response roles can do this

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Remediation Manager is the correct one. 
Remediation Manager can view and manage remediation actions taken by Falcon.
Endpoint Manager can manage sensor deployment, maintain sensor configuration and update policies and some other things, but related to maintenance of the sensors and such, not to remediations.

Selected Answer: B
It's B. End Point manager used to manage Sensor Deployment, maintain sensor config and update Policies not to modify remediation actions

questions.question_text: The alignment of a particular prevention policy to one or more host groups can be completed in which of the following locations within Falcon?

You have determined that you have numerous Machine Learning detections in your environment that are false positives. They are caused by a single binary that was custom written by a vendor for you and that binary is running on many endpoints. What is the best way to prevent these in the future?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Option D, “Using IOC Management, add the hash of the binary in question and set the action to ‘No Action’,” would not be effective because it doesn’t actively prevent the false positives. By setting the action to “No Action,” the system would continue to detect the binary but simply not take any action on it. This means the false positives would still appear in your detection logs, potentially cluttering them and making it harder to identify genuine threats.

On the other hand, setting the action to “Allow” (Option B) ensures that the binary is recognized as safe and prevents it from being flagged in the future, thus keeping your detection logs clean and focused on actual threats.

Selected Answer: B
Option B is the correct because it won't generate detection while option D will keep generating detection but won't take any action.
@DarkieCopy Allow is present in IOC, I just looked. Allow means it will not log the detection, "No Action" means it will still collect data on occurences.

comments.content: Check for Hash, for IP and Domain you have only Detect only and No Action

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Got to disagree with everyone: I think D is correct answer.
IOC management only allows "Detect only" and "No Action" among the possible actions, checked in console. Same happens in question #12. "Detect only" and "No Action" are the only possibilities in IOC management

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
B - Allow,do not detect

Selected Answer: B
I think B is correct

choices.A: Contact support and request that they modify the Machine Learning settings to no longer include this detection
choices.C: Using IOC Management, add the hash of the binary in question and set the action to "Block, hide detection"
choices.B: Using IOC Management, add the hash of the binary in question and set the action to "Allow"
choices.D: Using IOC Management, add the hash of the binary in question and set the action to "No Action"

questions.question_text: How long are detection events kept in Falcon?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Option A

Selected Answer: A
https://www.crowdstrike.com/products/endpoint-security/falcon-insight-edr/faq/
90 days only

Shoot it Could be A.Per the CCFA Checklist Notes " Data is only available in the Falcon UI for investigations, etc. through the company’s data retention time frame; detection information is kept for 90 days regardless; UI audits are available for 1 year

Selected Answer: B
Going to go with B, its either B or C . Bad question really.
I Think this is C, It says Detection Events. Events are stored for 7 Days
Activity feed (alerts) are kept 90 days. Events (EAM Data) depends on your contract
I think the right answer should be B

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Option - A

Note: CrowdStrike keeps detection data in the cloud for 90 days, after which some of the data gets purged from the database. Null icons indicate that some of the data for a process has started to be nullified. It could be a missing tactic, label, metadata or any part of the information pertaining to that process.
The wording of the question makes this confusing. Detections themselves are kept for 90 days but event data is only kept for the event retention set.

choices.A: Detection events are kept for 90 days
choices.B: Detections events are kept for your subscribed data retention period
choices.C: Detection events are kept for 7 days
choices.D: Detection events are kept for 30 days
